(still nothing [ALT: Rachel snorts]) The world thought it was wrong. But Maybe the world was wrong. Wrong about what could be, between a pillow and a boy... who became a man. Rachel snorts. dialogues.text: (chewing) Staaaaaaank. GREG’S DAD Yes, the smell is odd and repellent to our Western noses.

Anyway, we liked them so much that we started making our own.  24pt 24pt Green (06/20/2014) 22. INT. GREG’S LIVING ROOM - MANY YEARS AGO 24pt Now we are watching one of their films. dialogues.text: GREG'S DAD, attempting to grill SWEETBREADS, looks down i irritation - he has stepped onto some tracks and a CAMERA EQUIPPED TONKA TRUCK is banging into his feet - GREG’S DAD Boys! These sweetbreads need my absolute focus!

dialogues.text: They're all pretty horrible, but for some reason we keep making them. They all have the same signature ending. Young Earl has murdered Young Greg. He yells something in made-up language at the camera.

dialogues.text: Life is a meaningless dream, floating in eternal silence. (MORE )

dialogues.text: Life is the shadow of death. BLACKOUT, plus the giant words, “NOW YOU ARE DEAD.” 25 INT. GREG’S LIVING ROOM - PRESENT 25 GREG and EARL have just finished re-watching their movie. They are both munching squid. GREG’S DAD (from doorway ) Truly, one of my favorites from your oeuvre. A mature investigation into the nature of violence.

dialogues.text: Dad! For like the billionth time! You're not allowed to watch these! Greg’s dad shuffles away.

dialogues.text: Earl. First of all, if it’s that high-stakes, I probably won't even be able to get a boner.

dialogues.text: Did I say shit about boners? No. (beat) Now what kinda cancer even is acute myelogenous leukemia.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: You know. Cancer of the... thing. 26 EXT./INT. MCCARTHY’S CLASSROOM - THE NEXT DAY 26 Super: The part where I am even more of an idiot than nor The bell has just rung on the history class of MR. MCCART

dialogues.speaker: MR. MCCARTHY
dialogues.text: Okay. Class. Tomorrow, you must come armed with an epic fact. Just one fact. But it must be epic. CLASS. RESPECT THE RESEARCH.

dialogues.text: (half-heartedly) Respect the research. Mr. McCarthy punches his own biceps.

dialogues.speaker: FACTS.
dialogues.text: Greg approaches him as his classmates file out of the roo

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: Mr. McCarthy? Do you know any facts about, uh, leukemia?

dialogues.speaker: MR. MCCARTHY
dialogues.text: (kindly) Yes. Leukemia is cancer of the blood and/or bone marrow.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: So it’s pretty spread out in the body.  27 Blue (6/3/14) 24.

dialogues.speaker: MR. MCCARTHY
dialogues.text: Own the fact. Yes.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: How soon do people die from it?

dialogues.speaker: MR. MCCARTHY
dialogues.text: Well, it’s often very treatable, bud. Why do you ask?

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: You know Rachel Kushner has leukemia, right? This silences MR. MCCARTHY. Also OTHER NEARBY CLASSMATES (including MADISON). In retrospect, Greg has said this way too loud.

dialogues.text: Rachel has what? INT. RACHEL’S BEDROOM - THAT EVENING 27 GREG is back in RACHEL’S pillow-infested room. She is not happy. He has his head in his hands.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: I'm, like, innovatively stupid.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Everyone was going to find out sooner or later. I just hate having to share everything about myself. Greg is trying to think of a way to help.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: I’m the exact same way. Check it out. One thing you can do when you don’t want to deal with people is just enter a subhuman state. Rachel looks at him expressionlessly.

dialogues.speaker: GREG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Here, pretend you’re someone annoying.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: (impersonating an annoying classmate) Hi, Rachel. I’m really sorry you have cancer.  Blue (6/3/14) 25.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: (cross-eyed, sort of zombie-like) urrrrjj jjjunhjh uuhjjghjnj gnngnngh Rachel does not know what to think of this. It’s definite cute. It’s also deeply stupid.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Does that ever work?

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: It works all the time. It’s passive resistance. That’s what Gandhi was all about.

dialogues.text: I’m pretty sure Gandhi never did the subhuman thing.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: How do you think India achieved statehood? Try it: uurrrnng mnnurrrrjjrjjjj-

dialogues.text: (smiling) Nope.

dialogues.text: Come on! It’s easy. Or another thing you can do is just flat-out pretend to be dead. Check it out. Say something annoying to me.

dialogues.text: (nervously trying to ignore Hugh Jackman) urrngh  Blue (6/3/14) 26.

dialogues.text: No, seriously. Think about what you're doing here, dickhead. Jesus. Greg is now lying there with a horrified look on his face HUGH JACKMAN (CONT’D) I’ve been doing my broody Wolverine face on this girl’s wall for five and a quarter years, and at this point I’m probably only still here because she’d feel weirdly guilty or disloyal taking me down, but I’m goddamned if I’m letting a little punk like you waltz in here stupiding up the place--

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: (panicking) No yeah obviously but now I’m being all weird about it, and I can’t get un-weird, because I’m just an idiot and despite what you just said I’m clearly still sitting here thinking “death death death death death”-- Suddenly Rachel enters a subhuman state.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: huuurnnrnnnrnnh hurrnrnnrngghjh Greg processes this. For the first time in his life, a girl has understood him

Green (06/20/2014) 27. Rachel stops the subhuman state. Their eyes meet. There i makeout session.

dialogues.text: Anyway... Yup.

dialogues.text: Silence. Green (06/20/2014) 27A.

dialogues.text: Animals just live in our homes and everyone’s cool with it. Animals.

dialogues.text: It is kinda strange to think about.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: The hardest part is watching my mom try to deal with it. And sometimes, I mean, I do think... if it ends up that she’s alone, in that house... She has no one. She and my dad hate each other, she has no siblings... I don’t know what she’d do. Rachel is somber, but dry-eyed.

dialogues.text: I’m not crying.  Blue (6/3/14) 29.

dialogues.text: No. It was just the thing we did, when it was time for us to spend time together. We didn’t even talk while we were doing it. The only words we said were, like, “squirrel. Seven. ...two squirrels. Nine.”

dialogues.text: You need to apply for a dad refund immediately. 31pt2 INT. COPACETIC COMICS - LATER 31pt2 RACHEL and GREG’s conversation continues in the aisles of cluttered, venerable old comics/records/movies store--

dialogues.text: So what group am I in?  Blue (6/3/14) 30.

dialogues.text: You’re an asshole. What group are you in?

dialogues.text: I’m not. I wouldn’t belong in any group that doesn’t suck. I’m terminally awkward and I have a face like a groundhog.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: You can’t really think that!

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: I don’t think that, I know that. For a kid like me, best-case for high school is, just survive. That’s all you can hope for. Survive without creating a mortal enemy or hideously embarrassing yourself forever.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Just survive until college, huh.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: College? College is going to be even worse!

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: At least high school is over at three. And it’s kids I know by now. College is nonstop strangers! Some of them live in your room! You can literally never relax. I see myself dying of a panic attack two weeks in. I might just not apply.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: That's the dumbest thing I’ve ever heard you say.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: It’s probably not even top five. Look. High school, college... we're forced to spend these years of our lives in giant herds of randomly selected people we have nothing in common with. It’s a nightmare. Anyone who says otherwise is lying. Rachel gazes at this weird kid with the self-esteem defic

dialogues.text: (decisively) Congratulations, Greg. Tomorrow, you're eating lunch with Boring Jewish Senior Girls Subgroup 2a.

The giant red words “SYSTEM FAILURE” are flashing over everything and making that BURMP BURMP BURMP sound that m that a computer is about to explode.

dialogues.speaker: MADISON
dialogues.text: Hi guys. Can I sit with you? Anna and Naomi gaze at her with coolness, if not hostilit But RACHEL has re-arrived with her ketchup, so they can’t mean to her outright.

dialogues.text: Sorry, I have to carry this pillow around and pretend it’s a baby. For health class. This is a safe place to put it, right?

dialogues.text: Earl. Greg.

dialogues.speaker: MR. MCCARTHY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Boys, behold wisdom’s very source. Gaze into the waters of the oracle. Greg and Earl peer into the tureen. Earl’s description is accurate. It is a funky seaweed-looking tentacle soup.

dialogues.speaker: MR. MCCARTHY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s Vietnamese. They call it pho.

dialogues.speaker: EARL
dialogues.text: Lemme try some one time.

dialogues.speaker: MR. MCCARTHY
dialogues.text: (closing pot) Can't give you food. Totally verboten. Try Thuyen’s Saigon Flavor in Lawrenceville. Tell them to put it on my tab.

dialogues.speaker: EARL
dialogues.text: Ain’t goin to no Lawrenceville.

dialogues.speaker: MR. MCCARTHY
dialogues.text: (gently) Greg. How you holding up, bud? This is clearly a question about Rachel. Greg does not kn how to fight the implication that he and Rachel have a th

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: Holding up? Good. But not great. But I mean, stuff in general, ups and downs, take it as it comes. Life has many facets. So... amen.

dialogues.speaker: MR. MCCARTHY
dialogues.text: Amen. You owe me multiple essays. And that is a fact. Gentlemen!

dialogues.speaker: GREG AND EARL
dialogues.text: Respect the research. Mr. McCarthy beams, thumps his own abs, and leaves. Greg Earl immediately ladle SOUP into their mouths.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: People just assume Rachel and I are dating. And it’s ruining my life. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: GREG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Today I threatened to sexually assault a fake baby. Then I became mortal enemies with Scott Mayhew. Both of those are Rachel’s fault. I’m sorry. They just are. Earl stares at Greg, like, Greg. Don’t be a dick.

dialogues.speaker: GREG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (rebelliously) But somehow I’m the dick for complaining about it. Earl doubles down on his disgusted stare.

dialogues.speaker: GREG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (backing down) I mean I am a dick for complaining about it. I didn’t actually mean any of that.

dialogues.speaker: EARL
dialogues.text: Better play with them titties.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: Does this taste strange to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GREG is sitting in class. Something is wrong with him. He staring dully forward, a look of muted horror on his face Slow agonizing ZOOM on his face, scored to the eerie, melancholy descending chords of movement XIII., “Crucifix of the Mass in B Minor by J.S. Bach. SPLICE with Greg’s POV of the TEACHER, droning distantly unintelligibly as if underwater. GREG'S CLASSMATES all seem to be staring at him. A cartoon badger image flickers over his field of vision. The BUZZ OF HIS VIBRATING PHONE frightens the LIVING SHIT OF HIM. Greg looks at his phone. Earl has texted him a message: t soup had drugs . Greg looks up at the teacher in horror. SUPER: The part where I accidentally am on drugs The bell rings. Greg jumps to his feet. Then, immediately falls down.  35 36 Blue (6/3/14) 37.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Greg is in a crowded hallway, attempting to make his way of school. His eyes are wild and his movements clumsy. SPLICE with his ROBO-GREG POV, which is distorted and malfunctioning. The badger image continues to blip over h field of vision. Sometimes the badger has tentacles.

dialogues.speaker: GUYS CONFIRMED INCOMING
dialogues.text: classification: uhhh

dialogues.speaker: BADGER
dialogues.text: execute pigeon dance

dialogues.speaker: SYSTEM ERROR
dialogues.text: JUST DON’T LOOK AT ANYONE

dialogues.speaker: DON'T FALL DOWN OR LOOK AT ANYONE
dialogues.text: Suddenly and frighteningly, EARL is right in front of him

dialogues.speaker: EARL
dialogues.text: McCarthy must put weed in that soup. Because I am lit.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: Oh my God. I’m supposed to go see Rachel.

dialogues.speaker: EARL
dialogues.text: You do that. I’m goin to your house and grubbin on all your dad's food.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: No! You have to come help!

dialogues.speaker: EARL
dialogues.text: Help with what?

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: Help!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GREG is still wild-eyed, glancing around suspiciously, an trying to be less conspicuous by slouching in his seat. T behavior is extremely conspicuous. EARL tries to distract him--

dialogues.speaker: EARL
dialogues.text: In class do McCarthy act all stoned and shit?

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: Uh. I guess he, uh... Not all the time, but like, sometimes... or not sometimes, but... You know how he is, he’s uh... Huh.

dialogues.speaker: EARL
dialogues.text: Goddamn, son. You can’t even put a goddamn sentence together.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: It’s insane that Mr. McCarthy eats soup with drugs in it.

dialogues.speaker: EARL
dialogues.text: Keep your damn voice down. Indeed. Sitting behind them is SCOTT MAYHEW. He has heard everything.  Blue (6/3/14) 39. 38 EXT. RACHEL’S DOORSTEP 38 Greg and Earl are standing on the doorstep.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: (unnecessarily whispering) We can’t tell anyone we’re on drugs.

dialogues.speaker: EARL
dialogues.text: Why the hell not? Beat.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: Because then they’1ll know. Denise opens the door, swaying a little -

dialogues.speaker: DENISE
dialogues.text: It’s my humble little mouse! And who is his little mouse friend? Neither Greg nor Earl says anything. Then they both say something at the same time.

dialogues.speaker: EARL
dialogues.text: (too loud, borderline confrontational) Earl Jackson.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: Earl's just, uh, you know, he’s my coworker, and he’s a great guy, and we were just hanging out, uhhh... and not really doing anything, and Rachel’s about to lose all her hair, so we just wanted to say hey, you know, what’s up. Goodbye, hair. Good riddance. Because she is gonna look great without hair. That’s a fact. So we just wanted to say, what’s up. But Denise isn’t sober enough to realize they’re being we Sure.

dialogues.speaker: DENISE
dialogues.text: RACHEL! We've got two cute little mouse boys on our doorstep. (flirtatiously) Would you like a little cheese?

dialogues.speaker: GREG EARL
dialogues.text: Naw, we good. INT. RACHEL’S BEDROOM —- MOMENTS LATER 39 RACHEL is guarded; EARL, unreadable; GREG, malfunctioning

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Hello, Earl.

dialogues.speaker: EARL
dialogues.text: Hi, Rachel. I like your room.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Thank you. Greg thinks it’s too girly.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: No! This room is great! What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: EARL
dialogues.text: Course it’s girly. It’s a girl’s damn room. My room ain’t got no pictures of James Bond in no thong.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: (laughing nervously) But if it did... that’d be weird.  Blue (6/3/14) 41. An uneasy silence.

dialogues.speaker: EARL
dialogues.text: So Rachel. We came to check up on you.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: Yeah, chemotherapy. That really sucks.

dialogues.speaker: EARL
dialogues.text: (shoving Greg) Dude. Don’t say it sucks.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: It does kind of suck.

dialogues.speaker: EARL
dialogues.text: Yeah, but you gotta do it, so...

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: I guess. By this point Rachel and Earl are both staring at the gro Clearly Greg has to say something.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: Uhhhhh. Earl and Rachel look at him expectantly. Greg literally cannot think of a thing to say. He opens his mouth and ho words will come out.

dialogues.speaker: GREG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Buhhhhhh.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: (beginning to sound tearful) You guys can go if you want. Greg panics.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: We're on drugs.

dialogues.speaker: EARL
dialogues.text: (face in hands again) Goddamn.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Why are you on drugs?  Blue (6/3/14) 42.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: We're accidentally on drugs.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Accidentally?

dialogues.speaker: EARL
dialogues.text: McCarthy gave us some of his soup--

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: (hastily) Mr. McCarthy gave us some of his totally normal soup. But it was, uh, the last of the soup. So we had to go get more. From a restaurant. On the fifth floor of an office building. And in the same building there was a Jamaican embassy. No one knows where this is going.

dialogues.speaker: GREG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We got trapped in an elevator with a Rastafarian. He just hotboxed the whole elevator. We were in there for 25 minutes. We had to breathe the weird marijuana air. Earl. Am I right. Earl is utterly disgusted. But he has to go along with it

dialogues.speaker: EARL
dialogues.text: Yeah. That’s what happened. But thank God: Rachel thinks that these confused, lying b are being kind of sweet.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: You guys had quite an adventure.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: Being on drugs sucks... and then being around someone on drugs sucks... this whole situation sucks super bad and it’s all my fault--

dialogues.speaker: EARL
dialogues.text: Man, shut up. Makin errything about your druggy ass. (to Rachel) I’m in the mood for some damn ice cream. You like ice cream?  40 Blue (6/3/14) 43.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EARL and RACHEL are chatting. GREG is utterly absorbed in ice cream, holding it several inches in front of his face Super: The part where it turns out Earl holds nothing sac

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: So you know Greg from class?

dialogues.speaker: EARL
dialogues.text: I known Greg ever since we was little. You know I was in y’all’s kindergarten, right?

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: EARL
dialogues.text: Yeah. I remember you. You were the girl who called Justin Jones perverted, for showing girls the birthmark on his butt.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Oh my God! Yes!

dialogues.speaker: EARL
dialogues.text: Dude came running up to you. Showed you his butt. You was all calm. Said, “Justin. Only perverts show their butts.” I was right there.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: It’s amazing you remember that.

dialogues.speaker: EARL
dialogues.text: You was a hero. Shut his perverted ass right down. Never forget it.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: So you and Greg are coworkers?

dialogues.speaker: EARL
dialogues.text: Naw, we friends. He just hates callin anyone his friend. Dude’s got issues.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Yeah! He does! What’s going on?

dialogues.speaker: EARL
dialogues.text: Man, I don’t even know. Might be his folks. Dude’s mom always tellin him how handsome he is, which... he ain't. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: EARL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So he think he can’t trust nobody who's close to him. Dude’s weird- ass dad don’t socialize with nobody cept the cat. So that’s a role model ain’t got no friends. Bottom line, dude’s terrified to call anybody his friend. Because they might say, hold up, bro. I ain’t your friend. And then he’d have to kill himself.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Wow. (beat) But how are you “coworkers”? Earl regards her and silently comes to a decision.

dialogues.speaker: EARL
dialogues.text: Well, we uh... we make films.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Movies?

dialogues.speaker: EARL
dialogues.text: Yeah. We been makin em for years. We made like 42 films in total.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Greg, you never told me! GREG’S POV: Rachel’s voice is indistinct, underwater. He cannot hear over the “MURMF ORMF RUMF” sound of his own rapturous eat Also the beautiful harp music is playing.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO THIRD-PERSON
dialogues.text: Greg nods briskly, goes “mm-hmm,” and goes back to eating

dialogues.speaker: EARL
dialogues.text: We ain’t told nobody about em. They suck. I mean, they’re terrible.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: There’s no way they suck. Again, Earl appraises Rachel before speaking.

dialogues.speaker: EARL
dialogues.text: Well, you can see em for yourself if you want.  Blue (6/3/14) 45.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: (knowing that this is a big deal) Are you sure?

dialogues.speaker: EARL
dialogues.text: Hell yeah! Don’t even worry bout it. Just don’t be tellin nobody.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Of course I won’t. Earl stands up, pulling Greg up with him.

dialogues.speaker: EARL
dialogues.text: Aight, son. Get on your feet.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: Sounds good. (beat) Where are we going? 4l INT. GREG’S TV ROOM - TWENTY MINUTES LATER 41 The three of them are watching a Gaines/Jackson film. EAR stony-faced. RACHEL is enjoying it hugely. GREG looks ill. 42 EXT. SIDEWALK IN FRONT OF GREG’S HOUSE - AFTERWARD 42 RACHEL is about to walk back to her house. GREG is still despondent.

dialogues.speaker: EARL
dialogues.text: We can walk you home -

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: (indicating Greg, happily) He needs to recover, and you probably need to help. ALT: I think you guys might need some alone time.

dialogues.speaker: EARL
dialogues.text: That’s true. She hugs Earl, and turns to Greg -

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL GREG
dialogues.text: Thanks. Sure. She walks away, radiant.  Blue (6/3/14)

dialogues.speaker: GREG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Goddammit Earl--

dialogues.speaker: EARL
dialogues.text: Son, don’t even start. 45a.  43 Blue (6/3/14) 46. They sit there in silence, Earl serene, Greg fuming. GREG DAD appears behind them and mutely hands each of them a p foot to eat.

dialogues.speaker: GREG, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: So we're pretty far into this stupid story now, and you're probably saying to yourself, “Hey. I like this girl Rachel, and I’m gonna be pissed if she dies at the end.” So I’m just telling you: Don’t freak out. She survives. When I said someone dies, I meant someone else. So hopefully that reassures you. Although actually, why would it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MR. MCCARTHY sips from his thermos.

dialogues.speaker: MR. MCCARTHY
dialogues.text: Guys. I’m asking for one fact. This is probably the easiest thing you have been asked all day. Anyone. No one has a fact. Great. I’1l just call on you at random. Scott. Scott Mayhew is not psyched about being called on. Fortunately, he has a focal point for his irritation.

dialogues.speaker: SCOTT MAYHEW
dialogues.text: Fact: Greg was telling everyone that your soup has marijuana in it. The class now is stunned/giggly.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: I didn’t tell anyone!!

dialogues.speaker: SCOTT MAYHEW
dialogues.text: Greg, you are a liar and a coward. I heard you bellowing about it on public transit.

dialogues.speaker: MR. MCCARTHY
dialogues.text: Greg? Is that factual?

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: (defensively) Look. I’m sorry. But yesterday, Earl and I got stoned somehow. And it was after we both ate your soup. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: GREG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And we didn’t smoke any marijuana, which I never have done. So, your soup must have had drugs in it. Because that was the only thing we both ate, other than the cookies that Earl got from Ill Phil... the, uh, drug dealer... Aha.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GREG and EARL are exiting the school together.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: How did you not realize it was the cookies.

dialogues.speaker: EARL
dialogues.text: It was your stupid ass yellin shit on the bus! But behind them, the PRINCIPAL, and a SECURITY GUARD burs through the door, escorting an angry, struggling ILL PHIL the premises.

dialogues.speaker: ILL PHIL
dialogues.text: Greg! Did you snitch on me?

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: What? No, of course not. SCOTT MAYHEW has positioned himself nearby.

dialogues.speaker: SCOTT MAYHEW
dialogues.text: (to Ill Phil) He did snitch on you. I was there.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: Scott, what the hell. Scott draws close to Greg. He is a lot taller than Greg.

dialogues.speaker: SCOTT MAYHEW
dialogues.text: I heard you ridiculing me in front of your loathsome harem. (whispering intensely) Greg, I trusted you. You betrayed my trust. You trampled my dignity.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: It was like one time.

dialogues.speaker: SCOTT MAYHEW
dialogues.text: You have made a mortal enemy. I will never stop hounding you.  45 Blue (6/3/14) 48.

dialogues.speaker: ILL PHIL
dialogues.text: You got two mortal enemies. (whispering into Greg’s other ear) I stabbed a dude.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: Jesus.

dialogues.speaker: ILL PHIL
dialogues.text: (breaking determinedly into a flow) Kill you twenty different ways / Stab you with blades / Shoot you with death rays / Abandon you in a maze / Choke you on mayonnaise / The security guard drags him away. Greg and Earl turn to Scott Mayhew.

dialogues.speaker: SCOTT MAYHEW
dialogues.text: He, too, will never stop hounding you. Scott Mayhew spits on the ground near them and strides aw EXT./INT. RACHEL’S HOUSE/BEDROOM - AFTER FIRST ROUND OF C — NOVEMBER GREG is visiting RACHEL, and trying not to freak out abou how bad she looks. She is wearing a fuzzy pink hat. Her e are red-rimmed and her skin is pale. Super: The part where I hit on a girl who just had chemo

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: .»+.SO it’s been a month, and they haven't really done anything, but they did say, they’re never gonna stop hounding me, so, sooner or later, y'know... gonna get hounded.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: (distractedly) Mmmm. Greg looks around. All of the horizontal surfaces of her are overflowing with flowers and cards.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: Sorry. Next time I’1l bring flowers. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: GREG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Although where would I even put them? The only place left is the barf bucket.  Blue (6/3/14) Rachel doesn’t laugh at this.

dialogues.speaker: GREG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (helpfully) Ha ha! Flowers, where you barf. Still nothing.

dialogues.speaker: GREG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So, nice hat. It’s pretty cute. She looks at him. Then she erupts, miserably--

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Look. I was never very beautiful. And that was fine, because that’s not important to me. But I thought it’d be easier--to look like this, and it’s just not. Everyone comes in here and sees me--and they’re so clearly repulsed--and it’s so much harder than I thought it would be--

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: No. Come on. You look good.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: I look ugly... I’m so ugly, Greg. (gathering herself) I just feel very naked. I feel like my body’s on display, like some terrible exhibit: Girl With Cancer. (thoughtfully) It’s your worst nightmare actually, being exposed like this-- Something shuts her up. She stares at Greg. He is nervously fondling her boob.
She closes her eyes, and for a moment he thinks it is bec she is enjoying it. But she is not.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Greg... no.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: I’m not doing this because it might be your last chance to be with a man. I’m doing this because I can’t control myself. (beat) I want to play with those titties.  Blue (6/3/14)

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: (now really starting to break down) (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Everyone feels like they have to lie to me--and no one realizes how insulting that is--everyone thinks they're helping--and they’re not--

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: Sorry. Okay. It'd just be helpful to know what you want.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: There’s nothing you can give me. It’s fine. Just go. They lock eyes. He closes his. Then he rummages around in his backpack. He comes up with

dialogues.speaker: DVD,
dialogues.text: Beat. and hands it to her.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: (muttering) This one is called Mono Rash. It’s based on Rashomon. By Kurosawa. The plot is just Earl killing people. Because he has a rash. From mono. The STD. It’s really not very good. (beat) The fight scene at minute 26 is probably the best part.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: You don’t mind someone else watching your movies?

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: Of course I mind! I’d rather be tortured by North Koreans! But... you know. Another beat. Then Rachel smiles.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: You want to play with these titties.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: I do. Both titties. They’re both equally great. Her smile broadens--

dialogues.speaker: GREG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I should go. We’re supposed to work on our homage to Apocalypse Now. (beat) (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: GREG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ours is called A Box O’ Lips, Wow. So. That’s even worse than Mono Rash. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: GREG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I should just stay and talk you out of watching this--

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: No! I‘’1ll be fine. Go make it.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: I mean, we really shouldn't. It’s a war movie, where the two main guys take part in the unspeakable brutality of war and then find a box of tulips. Box o’ ‘lips. Yeah. They find it and are wowed. They just can’t get over how great these tulips are. So, “A Box O’ Lips, Wow.” The worst part is, tulips might not even be in the budget anymore -

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Please.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: Okay. He does not move. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: GREG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Have fun watching this incredibly terrible movie.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Have fun making the next one. EXT. EARL’S BACKYARD - AFTERNOON 46 GREG and EARL are having a heated production meeting. Earl is dressed in a makeshift soldier outfit, complete w gun. Greg has an armful of paratroopers. DERRICK, seated on the porch with a leashed Doopie, watch them with disdain.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: ++.SO you’re telling me we have no tulips AND no explosives.

dialogues.speaker: EARL
dialogues.text: Doopie ate em.

dialogues.speaker: DERRICK
dialogues.text: Ha HA. DOOP’D.  Blue (6/3/14) 52.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: Of course he did. Okay. I'll get explosives, you get tulips, meet you back here in an hour -—

dialogues.speaker: EARL
dialogues.text: Aw hell no. C’mon, man. I got a problem set -

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: Me too! I’ve got like twenty! I’m not gonna do any of them. I just... have them. Earl ponders their predicament.

dialogues.speaker: EARL
dialogues.text: Ima pitch you on something: Do we need tulips?

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: I can’t believe I’m hearing this. Earl. It’s A Box O’ ‘Lips, Wow. The box of tulips is the entire point. (spiralling out) We're gonna lose the light, your brother insists on being in the shot -

dialogues.speaker: DERRICK
dialogues.text: I’m the key grip! ALT: (Bane voice) When it is done, and Gotham is ashes, then you have my permission to die.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: - Dad’s using the good camera, that dog always freaks me out, this is a nightmare, why are we doing this.

dialogues.speaker: MADISON
dialogues.text: Oh my God! Are you guys making one of your movies right now?! What. Where the fuck did MADISON come from. She is leanin against the chain-link fence, beaming at them. All three boys stare at her: Greg in horror, Earl in confusion, Derrick with undisguised appreciation.

dialogues.speaker: MADISON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh my God. I’m on set right now. I can’t handle it. Action!! Cut!!!  Blue (6/3/14) 53.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: This isn’t a movie! It’s just a... (what could this even be?) I’ve been kidnapped!!

dialogues.speaker: EARL
dialogues.text: (ignoring Greg) Madison what you doin round here?

dialogues.speaker: MADISON
dialogues.text: (letting herself into the backyard) I was just visiting Rachel, and she was watching one of your secret movies, and first of all, I have to say it is so so sweet of you guys to let her see them. She wouldn’t even let me see them! So I know they’re 100% a huge secret.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: I haven't actually been kidnapped.

dialogues.speaker: MADISON
dialogues.text: I know. This is the biggest secret ever. Greg, I’m just so touched by how good of a friend you're being to her. Greg decides that now is the time for excessive modesty.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: I’m not that good of a friend.

dialogues.speaker: MADISON
dialogues.text: No, really. Greg. You’re being a good friend to her.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: No I’m really not.

dialogues.speaker: MADISON
dialogues.text: Are you serious right now? Greg. She told me. That you’ve been a great friend.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: She was probably lying.

dialogues.speaker: EARL
dialogues.text: Greg. Hell’s wrong with you. Accept a damn compliment.

dialogues.speaker: DERRICK
dialogues.text: Ma you want my number one time?  Blue (6/3/14) 54-56.

dialogues.speaker: MADISON
dialogues.text: No thanks. Anyway, I tracked you down because I had a huge brainstorm and I thought - what if you made a movie for Rachel? Brief BLACKOUT with the words “NOW YOU ARE DEAD.”

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: That’s not a good idea.

dialogues.speaker: MADISON
dialogues.text: It’s an amazing idea. It would be her favorite thing in the entire world. Please just think about it? Greg looks at Earl. Earl looks at Greg like, this is your problem, and you need to deal with it.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: Word. Earl winces.

dialogues.speaker: MADISON
dialogues.text: Did you just say, “Word”?

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: Yeah, word, like, I agree.

dialogues.speaker: MADISON
dialogues.text: So you agree! To make a movie for Rachel! AAAHHHHHH She clutches his arm. MOOSE CHIPMUNK STOMPING.

dialogues.speaker: MADISON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (leaving) Oh my God I can’t wait to see it. I have to run. You guys are the best. Rolling!! That’s a wrap!! Ha ha! The boys watch her go.

dialogues.speaker: DERRICK
dialogues.text: Titties.

dialogues.speaker: DECEMBER
dialogues.text: GREG, holding the ENORMOUS COLLEGE DIRECTORY under one ar finds RACHEL in the hospital’s cheery modern lounge. She watching one of his movies on her laptop. She pauses it as she approaches.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: (happily) “Droogle”?

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: Google for droogs. It’s stupid. Greg is in a foul mood.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: (indicating directory) What’s that?

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: Oh, nothing. Just the bane of my existence. Which my mom is forcing me to carry around. Until I apply to some colleges. She says it’s like a menu for my future. Sure. A menu that only has food that will humiliate you for four years. So it’s kind of a Mexican standoff, in which I carry this thing around forever, until my mom has irritated me to death. Which will happen in, tops, two days. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: You have to be less of an idiot about college. Listen. Even if you don’t think your classmates will like you, which is literally an insane thing to think, you’re way less exposed to them in college. High school is 40 hours of class a week. College is 15-20. And if you don’t want to live with other kids, go to school around here! Go to Pittsburgh State! Live at home! Don’t get me wrong. I think living at home would be unnecessary and stupid. But it’s better than sitting college out just because you irrationally hate yourself.  Blue (6/3/14) 58-59.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: (cowed) Not “irrationally,” though--

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Just apply to Pitt State right now. Apply early. (she nods at her computer) Do it right now, in front of me. Let’s get this out of the way.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: What if I say no?

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: I’ve got stage four cancer. (beat) So that would be pretty dick.

dialogues.speaker: UGGH FINE.
dialogues.text: They sit down. He melodramatically takes her computer and begins typing:

dialogues.speaker: GREG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: “Why I want to go to college.” (defiantly, to Rachel) By Werner Herzog. Rachel shrugs: bring it on.

dialogues.speaker: GREG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (Werner Herzog voice) The highly selective admissions process of college weeds out the cruel and the stupid. And so a college is quite different from the senseless chaos and sickening enormity of high school. High school is the mouth of a great demon, biting and chewing and smushing people in the face. It is simply overwhelming. (dropping the Herzog voice) In seriousness, I am looking forward to college because I never fit in in high school. Because of my weird rodent face -

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Nope -  Beat. Blue (6/3/14) 58-59A.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: And habit of saying the dumbest possible shit -

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: The sheer pastiness of my complexion overwhelms all who behold it with existential nausea -

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: (overriding him) “In high school, I never truly got comfortable in my own skin. In fact, I’ve always been someone who doesn’t like himself very much. But I think that just means I have some growing up to do. And college is the place where I’m going to do it.”

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: (deeply uncomfortable) That’s way too personal.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: It’s a personal essay.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: Fine. But only because, cancer. (briskly typing) And, you have to do this too now. Okay? Here. Page through this huge horrible book. It’s yours now. Find some colleges. Mmmmmmmmmm. It’s like a menu for your future.  53 54

dialogues.speaker: A55
dialogues.text: 55 Blue (6/3/14) 60. Done typing, he thrusts the COLLEGE DIRECTORY at her and pages randomly through it. Rachel smiles at him.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Can I finish my movie first?

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED 54
dialogues.text: EXT. RACHEL’S HOUSE - AFTER THE SECOND ROUND OF CHEMO - A

dialogues.speaker: EARLY DECEMBER
dialogues.text: GREG sits on the front steps; DENISE’S car pulls up; Greg goes to help Rachel out of the car. INT. RACHEL’S BEDROOM - AFTER THE SECOND ROUND OF CHEMO -

dialogues.speaker: DECEMBER
dialogues.text: MONTAGE - The days melt into each other. Fall becomes win Greg and Rachel watch movies together. Super: Day 24 of Doomed Friendship  56 57 Blue (6/3/14) 61. ON THE SCREEN: Earl is Rizzo from Midnight Cowboy, under blanket, dead on the bus to Florida; next to him, cowboy- hatted Greg is extravagantly freaking out. ON RACHEL’S BED: Greg is holding popcorn; Rachel holds a bucket. INT. GREG’S HOUSE - AFTER THE SECOND ROUND OF CHEMO -— 56

dialogues.speaker: DECEMBER
dialogues.text: Greg and Rachel watch movies. Super: Day 31 of Doomed Friendship ON THE SCREEN: Earl is Jean-Paul Belmondo in the last sce of Breathless, running spastically down the street. IN THE BAY WINDOW: Greg eats popcorn; Rachel, looking a little better, nibbles some too. INT. HOSPITAL, RACHEL’S ROOM - THIRD ROUND OF CHEMO -— 57

dialogues.speaker: JANUARY
dialogues.text: Greg and Rachel watch movies in her hospital room. Super: Day 45 of Doomed Friendship ON THE SCREEN: A Gaines/Jackson film (TBD). AT THE HOSPITAL: Rachel, looking worse, has fallen asleep Greg looks over at her. He fades the volume to silent, takes the barf bucket out her hands, and pulls her blanket over her. He pulls out his phone and checks his email. He has one f Pittsburgh State University - Admissions Dept. It begins, Greg Gaines, We are pleased to... He is happier than he thought he’d be. But he has no one share it with - Rachel is asleep. So he does an awkward silent fist pump. “NOW YOU ARE DEAD,” the movie tells him. He has a sudden worry. Discreetly, he puts his hand over mouth, to see if she is dead. She is not, thank God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GREG is walking through a little-used corridor. A RANDOM is putting up medieval decorations in the hall.

dialogues.speaker: RANDOM GIRL
dialogues.text: Buy tickets for prom! A “Knight” to “Remember”! Only four months away!!

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: (to himself) Why are there even quotation marks around “Remember” ?-- Greg is AMBUSHED by MADISON -

dialogues.speaker: MADISON
dialogues.text: Greg! Rachel said you got into Pitt State early!

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: Oh! Yeah. Clearly they’1l take anybody -

dialogues.speaker: MADISON
dialogues.text: I got in too!! AAAHHHH She hugs him and dances around--he is overjoyed but also nervous that he will get a boner--

dialogues.speaker: MADISON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So how’s the movie for Rachel coming?

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: (panicking) Uh... Good. But Pitt State! Can you believe it? And we got prom! ...In four months!

dialogues.speaker: MADISON
dialogues.text: I know. But I’m the most excited to see your moVIEEEEE AAAHHHHHH

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: (terrified, feigning joy)

dialogues.speaker: AAAAAHHHHHH
dialogues.text: 59 Blue (6/3/14) 63. EXT./INT. GREG’S KITCHEN - THAT AFTERNOON 59 EARL is eating pate. GREG is freaking out. Super: The part where I try to convince Earl to help me m The Worst Film Ever Made

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: ...so if we make this film, people will be like, oh, Greg and Earl, they’re those weird filmmakers. They're always creepily filming stuff. They probably sneak up to your house at night and film you while you’re asleep.

dialogues.speaker: EARL
dialogues.text: (chewing) This is nasty as hell.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: But people probably already think that. Because you gave those stupid films to Rachel. So basically I've become completely conspicuous, like, all the time. People look at me, they think, filmmaker. When they’re not already thinking, cancer girl’s boyfriend.

dialogues.speaker: EARL
dialogues.text: (examining container) The hell even is this. This taste like a dog's funky-ass butthole.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: Furthermore, we agreed to do a film, that we don’t even have any idea what it should look like, or sound like, or be. What the hell film can we even make? (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: GREG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What was I thinking?!

dialogues.speaker: EARL
dialogues.text: You were thinking, that girl Madison got big-ass titties. I like the titties. And now, you got a problem. You agreed to this shit, not me.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: Are you not gonna help me make this? Earl stares him down while eating another pate-laden crac

dialogues.speaker: EARL
dialogues.text: The hell we gonna make, son?

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: Just something that says, Rachel! Hey! Keep living your life! (beat) It doesn’t suck!

dialogues.speaker: EARL
dialogues.text: Just gotta make it look like it don’t suck.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: That’s the thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GREG'S DAD explains the boys’ mission to a GRIZZLED OLD

dialogues.speaker: EMPLOYEE -
dialogues.text: GREG’S DAD They want fresh inspiration. I must tell you, the richest inspiration I have ever known was during my period of quarantine in the Amazon, where I and a half-dozen other unfortunates had nothing to watch but the bristling, leviathan spiders bunched on the rotting, flimsy thatch perhaps eight feet above our faces. Spiders the size of your fist. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: GREG'S DAD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Their fangs glistening with venom and their thousandfold black eyes shining dully in the gloom. And all the night long they would battle the wasps. In the darkness you would hear a sudden anguished hiss as a spider was struck by an adult leopard wasp, and in their mortal struggle they would plummet onto one’s bed, biting and stinging and thrashing and - - as EARL and GREG split up and peruse the aisles of movi with terrific intensity. Greg slows down in a little zone of experimental filmmake EAMES, FISCHINGER, BRAKHAGE, MAYSLESES, WARHOL. INTERCUT his scrutiny of their DVD cases with SNIPPETS OF ANIMATIONS THEMSELVES, as he replays each in his mind’s e Clutching handfuls of these DVDs, he looks over at Earl. brandishes some GODZILLA KNOCK-OFFS. Greg shakes his head Earl nods, like, yeah, I know, but Godzilla is still the fucking best.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 62 Blue (6/3/14) 66. INT. RACHEL’S LIVING ROOM - AFTERNOON 62 EARL is working the cameras while GREG, holding a noteboo is attempting to interview DENISE, who is openly drinking (RACHEL is in the hospital for her fourth round of chemo. It’s not entirely clear that Denise knows that they’re ma a film, or cares.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: So, Denise, can you tell us a little about Rachel’s birth?

dialogues.speaker: DENISE
dialogues.text: Rachel’s birth. What an ordeal. (beat) Greg, listen to me. Listen. I've been a good mother to her. Some single moms, their kids have to grow up too fast. But I’ve tried to protect her from that. I have.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: Uh, right.

dialogues.speaker: DENISE
dialogues.text: And now I’m learning, some things, you can’t protect your kid from. No matter what you do. Denise sips from her glass of bourbon, her gunmetal eyes reflecting some tiny part of the crushing horror of it.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: So did she have a favorite toy?

dialogues.speaker: DENISE
dialogues.text: Promise me one thing. You’re gonna grow up, become an adult. Promise me you won’t have a baby unless you're ready to love that baby’s mother, your whole life.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: So, no favorite toy.

dialogues.speaker: DENISE
dialogues.text: “Toy”? Here’s a toy. Scissors. Bill left and she rounded up all his precious old books and cut em right up. Don’t tell her I told you. I was like, atta girl. Snip, snip, snip. HA. Denise starts pouring drinks for Greg and Earl.  63 64 Blue (6/3/14) 67.

dialogues.speaker: DENISE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Have a little taste with me. You’re old enough to have a little taste.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is empty, save for GREG and EARL sitting in chai with clipboards and a STUDENT, sitting in a chair, facing camera on a tripod. Greg is trying to mask how depressed and upset this is ma him. Earl physically cannot stop scowling.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: «+.SO just think of it like a get- well card, except it’s a video. And start whenever you’re ready.

dialogues.speaker: TESTIMONIAL STUDENT
dialogues.text: (with glib, smiley insincerity) Uh. Hi, Rachel. I guess I don’t know you that well, but uh... I believe in you. (beat) You can do it! That is all that this kid has to say.

dialogues.speaker: EARL
dialogues.text: (sullenly) That’s real nice. POV of camera on tripod:  65 66 Green (06/20/2014) 68.

dialogues.speaker: TESTIMONIAL STUDENT
dialogues.text: It’s so sweet that your boyfriend is doing this for you! He must really love you. (Greg says something inaudible offscreen) Oh.

dialogues.speaker: TESTIMONIAL STUDENT
dialogues.text: I know you’re Jewish, but I just want you to know, God has a plan for you.

dialogues.speaker: TESTIMONIAL STUDENT
dialogues.text: (can’t stop crying)

dialogues.speaker: TESTIMONIAL STUDENT
dialogues.text: Greg's a fag. I guess he’s in love with you, so that makes him bisexual or something. I hope they find a cure for whatever you have. (to Greg, offscreen) That’s all I got, fag.

dialogues.speaker: TESTIMONIAL STUDENTS
dialogues.text: (jump cuts) I believe in you. I believe in you. I believe in you. You can do it! INT. GREG’S BEDROOM - LATER 65 GREG and EARL have just finished watching the footage.

dialogues.speaker: EARL
dialogues.text: (eventually) Damn. INT. RACHEL’S BEDROOM - DIRECTLY AFTER FOURTH ROUND OF 66

dialogues.speaker: CHEMO
dialogues.text: RACHEL sits stiffly on the bed. GREG sits next to her wit her barf bucket on his lap. They’re watching a Gaines/Jackson film, but she’s not enjoying it as much as she used to. So he’s not enjoying this, either. +e * HF  Green (06/20/2014) 68A.

dialogues.speaker: GREG, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: So again, if this was a touching romantic story, we'd obviously fall in love, and she’d say all the wise beautiful things that can only be learned in life’s twilight or whatever, and then she’d die in my arms. But again: that’s not what happened. She just got quieter, and unhappier.  Blue (6/3/14) 69. Greg finally can’t be quiet anymore--

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: Hey. How are you feeling, for real.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: For real? I’m feeling like you might have been right.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: Right when?

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Back in October. When you thought I was dying.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: (gutted/trying to recover) Oh. Well. I regret thinking that.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Don’t regret it. This is so miserable that Greg actually has to make a jok

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: Urrrnrrnnnngh. (after no response) Urrrnnnrnrnnnnnrnggggghggh.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: What is that noise.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: Regretful Polar Bear. Against her will, Rachel snort-laughs a little bit.

dialogues.speaker: GREG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Polar bears have the purest expressions of regret in the animal kingdom. Listen to how haunting and plaintive they sound. Urrrrnnrnngh.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Don’t make me laugh, though. It kind of hurts.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: (sadly) All right. A long beat.

dialogues.speaker: GREG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Kind of a monster silence in here.  Blue (6/3/14) 69A.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Yeah. It’s okay to just be silent for a while. Greg finds it difficult to be silent. He fidgets and squi He starts making a humming noise.

dialogues.speaker: GREG, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Look. I know you're really bracing for this sweet girl, that you probably like a lot, to die. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: GREG, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Just please bear with me. She doesn’t. She gets better. I promise. INT. GREG’S BEDROOM - THE NEXT DAY 67 GREG and EARL are creating an ABSTRACT STOP-MOTION ANIMAT Earl is creating little CUT-OUTS from FELT OR CONSTRUCTIO PAPER. He is dissatisfied with each one. Greg is arranging them painstakingly under a camera on a tripod, consulting the complex sketches he has made to gu this process.

dialogues.speaker: STOP-MOTION ANIMATION
dialogues.text: SUPERS over the frames of this animation: Day 86 of Doome Friendship, Day 87 of Doomed Friendship, Day 88 of Doomed Friendship, etc. Each day is about a tenth of a second.

dialogues.speaker: GREG, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: This is pretty much all I remember from that winter. Entire months of my life, where all I remember is making a shape move around (ALT TBD). And yeah, I’m aware of how cosmically depressing that sounds.  69 70 Blue (6/3/14) 71.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JUMPCUTS of GREG walking to Rachel’s house, entering her room, leaving her room, leaving her house, waiting on her doorstep as Denise’s car pulls up (back from the hospital

dialogues.speaker: GREG, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I mean, obviously I remember visiting Rachel too. What I don’t remember is doing schoolwork. I’m not exaggerating when I tell you that I did literally zero schoolwork during this time. I mean, literally zero. That’s actually sort of hard to do. INT. RACHEL’S BEDROOM - AFTER 5TH CHEMO ROUND - APRIL - D RACHEL looks terrible. There’s no way to get around it.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: So what's going on at school.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: The entire school looks like a castle, because medieval prom is about to happen. I guess everyone is trying to figure out how to twerk, like, medievally.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Are you going?

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: Of course not.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: You should go.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: No way. Have you seen me in a tux? It’s like when they make a dog wear human clothes. It just makes you sad to look at it. Anyway, I don’t have anyone to go with. Greg realizes that he is talking to a girl.

dialogues.speaker: GREG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (with great effort) I mean, uh... unless you... wanted to, uh...

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Greg, I’m not going to prom.  Blue (6/3/14) 72.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: No, you totally could. It could be this awesome statement, like--

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: (cutting him off) Hey. When are you gonna finish your movie?

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: My movie? You know I’m not working on a movie.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: You don’t have to pretend. Earl’s been telling me about it. Somehow it hurts a lot, that this surprise has been ruine

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: He... yes, I guess he probably did.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Sorry. I’m just asking because--

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: Goddamn Earl. It was supposed to be a surprise for you. It’s just taken forever, because we really want to get it right--

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: I think I’m probably gonna stop treatment pretty soon. It is very quiet in the room for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: It just isn’t doing me any good. All it’s doing is making me even sicker.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: Yeah, but if you stop... He can’t finish this sentence.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: We'll just see what happens.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: We know what’s gonna happen.  Blue (6/3/14) 73. Rachel studies him.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: I know who you can take to prom.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: This sexy pillow here.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: Oh my God. Please don’t make jokes right now. I can’t deal with that.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Oooh, Greg. This pillow’s name is Francesca. She’s a filthy Italian woman.

dialogues.speaker: STOP IT.
dialogues.text: It is the first time he’s ever shouted at her.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Don’t yell at me.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: So you’re just gonna give up. That’s it. To hell with college. To hell with the future.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Greg, don’t--

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: You're just gonna give up and die. What the hell is wrong with you? It’s your life.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: (spurred to anger) Yes, it is my life. And it’s me lying in bed all the time, with a shaved head, and getting weaker and uglier and more miserable, with no hope in sight--I’m the one suffering through this, not you. So don’t yell at me. They are trembling with anger at each other.  Blue (6/3/14) 74.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. I’m not going to get comfortable with watching you die. I’m just not. So don’t ask me to.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: If you can’t accept that I’m going to do what I want to do, with my life, then you're a terrible friend.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: I’m a terrible friend? I’m not giving up. I’m not ruining my friend’s life by giving up on the whole world.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Please. Greg, you should be overjoyed. Now you can go back to your life of being invisible and detached and self-hating.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: Yeah and you can go back to your life of being dead.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Nice. Really nice.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: This is gonna kill your mom. So you've gotten comfortable with that? It doesn’t bother you anymore, thinking about your mom?

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Get out of here, Greg. You’ve done your time. You don’t have to hang out with the sick girl anymore.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: How can you--how can you even say that?

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Your mom forced you to hang out with me. Earl forced you to show me your movies. Madison forced you to make a movie for me. So yeah. What part of any of that did you actually want to do? Greg opens his mouth--but he has no response to this.  Blue (6/3/14) 15.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do something nice for me for once. And get out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Greg is walking to Earl’s house, through Earl’s dilapidat neighborhood. He is muttering furiously to himself. All o his anger and frustration is now channeled at Earl. Super: The part where I get in my first fight ever

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: Earl. EARL. This is it. You’ve gone too far. You’ve leaked the unleakable secret. Because you hold nothing sacred. Because you're a dickhead. A tough-looking kid watches Greg pass.

dialogues.speaker: GREG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The foundation of any good working partnership is trust. I can no longer trust you in any way. He takes a clumsy tripping step on the broken pavement. H begins to hyperventilate.

dialogues.speaker: GREG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You'll leak anything to anyone. It’s like working with Julian... Assange. Greg does not know how to pronounce “Assange.” This only serves to infuriate him further.

dialogues.speaker: GREG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ass-andge. (beat) Assangggeh. (beat) DAMMIT. A72 EXT. EARL’S HOUSE - LATER A72 GREG thumbs Earl an angry text. EARL’S BROTHER DERRICK saunters out onto the porch, with DOOPIE on a leash.

dialogues.speaker: DERRICK
dialogues.text: Hell you want.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: I’m just waiting for Earl.  Blue (6/3/14) 75A. Derrick eyes Greg. So does Doopie, growling. Greg’s anger now vying with his fear. It is a relief, but not really, when Earl appears.  Blue (6/3/14) 16.

dialogues.speaker: EARL
dialogues.text: Sup. You gonna come in?

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: No, I’m good.

dialogues.speaker: DERRICK
dialogues.text: Oh no. Uh-oh.

dialogues.speaker: EARL
dialogues.text: The hell you want, bro.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: Uh, I was just talking to Rachel, and she, uh, told me you told her, uh, about the uh, the film. We were making. For her.

dialogues.speaker: EARL
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: You're like, uh, Julian Ass-andge.

dialogues.speaker: EARL
dialogues.text: The shit is that.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: It’s just, you know, I mean, you always do this, because you want to be a better friend than me or something. So you just tell Rachel about everything, and it’s like, it doesn’t even matter what I want.

dialogues.speaker: EARL
dialogues.text: You know what? Shut the hell up. You need to shut the hell up right about now. I’m tired of this, man. I’m about to lose my shit with you. Earl advances down the steps of his porch on an increasin trembly, weepy Greg.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: (trying hard not to cry) I just, I can’t trust you, and I don't know if I can work with, with you again--  Blue (6/3/14) 77.

dialogues.speaker: EARL
dialogues.text: Naw. Shut the hell up. You care so goddamn much bout what other people think, gotta go round kissin errybody’s ass pretendin like you they friend, well lemme tell you: nobody give a shit about you. Nobody... give a shit.

dialogues.speaker: DERRICK
dialogues.text: Whoop his ass!

dialogues.speaker: EARL
dialogues.text: And now this one girl come along, the only girl that do give a shit, and you start whinin and bitchin cuz I told her about the damn films. Bitchin and complainin because somebody cares about your shit. DAMN.

dialogues.speaker: EARL
dialogues.text: Goddamn I’m sick and tired a watchin you treat this girl like a burden. She is about to die. You know that, right? That girl is about to die. Meanwhile you come to my house whinin and cryin bout some irrelevant bullshit. Goddamn I want to bust your ass. I want... to beat the hell out of you right now.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: Go for it.

dialogues.speaker: EARL
dialogues.text: You want me to?

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: I don’t care.

dialogues.speaker: EARL
dialogues.text: Bitch, you want me to?

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: Yeah, Earl, I want you tOOOONGH Earl socks Greg in the stomach. Greg immediately keels ov

dialogues.speaker: DERRICK
dialogues.text: Yeah! JACK THAT LITTLE DUDE UP.  72 Blue (6/3/14) 78. But Earl does not jack that little dude up. He storms bac inside his house, furious. Wheezing and choking back sobs, Greg gets to his feet. He looks at the house. Derrick gazes coolly back at him.

dialogues.speaker: DERRICK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’da whooped the hell out of you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GREG is sullenly eating alone. MR. MCCARTHY walks in to refill his thermos.

dialogues.speaker: MR. MCCARTHY
dialogues.text: Beast. Where’s the other beast?

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: Earl? I don’t know. He’s not here. Mr. McCarthy gamely tries again.

dialogues.speaker: MR. MCCARTHY
dialogues.text: What’s the status with the twenty- pager on Nixon?

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: I need another extension.

dialogues.speaker: MR. MCCARTHY
dialogues.text: It’s the end of the quarter, bud.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: Well, I’ve been busy. Mr. McCarthy observes Greg.

dialogues.speaker: MR. MCCARTHY
dialogues.text: (more quietly) I heard the latest about Rachel. (beat) How are you holding up.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: You know... not great.

dialogues.speaker: MR. MCCARTHY
dialogues.text: I was fifteen when my Dad died. Couple years younger than you. Greg is startled by this.  Blue (6/3/14) 79.

dialogues.speaker: MR. MCCARTHY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You know what I remember about it? My whole childhood I just thought of him as this big, quiet, kind of asshole guy. Didn’t laugh much. Liked his sons to wear ties. And then at the wake, all his old buddies are there telling me about him, and it’s like they’re talking about a complete other guy. Like, he knew every European pop song from the 70s, from when he was stationed in Germany. He’d just sit around memorizing songs to sing at German girls in bars. His go-to was this Dutch song called Ding-A-Dong. That's a real song. And he sang it at German girls in bars.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: So what does that mean.

dialogues.speaker: MR. MCCARTHY
dialogues.text: It just means that, even if someone dies, you're still gonna keep learning about them. You know? Their life keeps unfolding to you, if you keep paying attention to it.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: (sullenly) What, if you're like a historian? Are you seriously trying to make this into some stupid sappy lesson? Mr. McCarthy smiles at Greg and gets to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: MR. MCCARTHY
dialogues.text: You're a good kid, Greg.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: I’m not.

dialogues.speaker: MR. MCCARTHY
dialogues.text: You're a good goddamn kid.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: (gathering his stuff) Look. I’m going home. I’m cutting school right in front of you. I’m not a good kid. Mr. McCarthy says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: GREG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (leaving) I’m not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GREG is slumped in a seat, staring without seeing out of window, as the bus rumbles home. INT. GREG’S KITCHEN - A HALF-HOUR LATER 73 On his way in, GREG passes his DAD, munching sausage. GREG’S DAD Earl came by earlier to drop something off, but he turned down this superb Andouille rabbit sausage, which is quite unlike him - is everything all right? Greg does not respond. INT. GREG’S BEDROOM 74 GREG finds a DVD on his desk. On it is scrawled, in Sharp “IM OUT.” He plays the DVD. It’s of EARL, talking to the camera, in Greg’s room.

dialogues.speaker: EARL
dialogues.text: Hi Rachel. We tried a bunch of different ways of making a film for you, and all of em turned out goofy, and irrelevant, and not like we wanted. So now I’m just gonna talk to you directly. (collects himself) I'ma be honest here. Sometimes white girls are a particular kind of stupid. I mean errbody stupid but you know. White girls think they smarter than errbody. Self- centered and pretendin like they ain’t - well, obviously you ain’t been like that. (collects himself again) It’s just crazy how patient you been. That’s all I wanted to say. If it was me at had cancer, I'd be angry as hell, and... and hurtful, and just tryna beat errybody’s ass half the time. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: EARL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So I’m just amazed at how patient you been. And you've made me feel, uh, blessed. (now pissed off; also a little husky-voiced) Greg, I ain’t workin on this no more. Do whatever the hell you want. I’m out.  75 Blue (6/3/14) 81. Earl switches off the camera and the clip ends, leaving G alone in his room. Greg holds his head in his hands. Then he flips on the camera. And tries to do a testimonia his own.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: Hi Rachel. Uh... Earl’s right. All the ways we tried to make a film for you turned out completely horrible. So, yeah. It got me thinking about the reason I wanted to do this film. He pauses. The fact is, he never wanted to do this film.

dialogues.speaker: GREG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And that reason is, when you come right down to it, and just say it, simply, without screwing around: He has to say something.

dialogues.speaker: GREG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Uh... I believe in you. He is quoting the first video testimonial, from that stup kid. He’s not even saying his own meaningless clichéd thi It’s something else's. He can’t bring himself to look at the camera. He’s lookin down, at his hands.

dialogues.speaker: GREG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (finally, sadly) You can do it. He is silent. Then he shuts off the camera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GREG opens the door to Mr. McCarthy’s office. EARL is in there, eating one of his all-candy lunches. On a screen behind him plays MY BEST FIEND, KLAUS KINSKI.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: Oh. Are you eating lunch in here still?

dialogues.speaker: EARL
dialogues.text: Not if you are.  76 77 Blue (6/3/14) 82.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: Well, I’m not eating in here if you are.

dialogues.speaker: EARL
dialogues.text: Well, good. Cuz I like it in here.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: So I guess I'll just go. Or, you could go.

dialogues.speaker: EARL
dialogues.text: Nope. I like the air-conditioning, and I like the comfortable chairs.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: Yeah, I like those too.

dialogues.speaker: EARL
dialogues.text: Well, that’s your damn problem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GREG trudges sadly through his personal hell: the cafeter One flying bit of food hits his face, then another. He finds a place to sit alone. Over his head, a banner re SCHENLEY SENIOR PROM “2013” A “KNIGHT” TO “REMEMBER” !!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He eats alone in the same seat, day after day, forlorn an withdrawn. He is checking his email on his phone, despondently - (we can’t read the body, but it’s from Pittsburgh State University) - when someone sits down in front of him. It is MADISON. Arm touch/MOOSE SMUSHES CHIPMUNK WITH HOOVES.

dialogues.speaker: MADISON
dialogues.text: Greg. I need to talk to you about the movie.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: It’s not done yet.  Blue (6/3/14) 82A.

dialogues.speaker: MADISON
dialogues.text: Greg. You've been working on this movie for like four months.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: Yeah, we tried a bunch of things. They just aren’t very good.  78 Blue (6/3/14) 83.

dialogues.speaker: MADISON
dialogues.text: UGH. Greg. Now is not the time for your whole, I’m-Greg, I-suck, nothing-I-do-is-any-good thing. I’m sure what you have is awesome and Greg I really think it can make a difference if you just put it together and give it to her.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: (bitterly) Madison, she’s stopped treatment. She gave up. She quit. Madison gazes at him. Her eyes glisten.

dialogues.speaker: MADISON
dialogues.text: (icily) So maybe that’s a good reason to finish the stupid movie. And give it to her. (more so) But you know what? Whatever. She stalks away. INT. GREG’S BEDROOM - THAT AFTERNOON 78 GREG is watching his testimonial to Rachel. He watches himself mumble, “I believe in you.” Pathetic. He rewinds and plays it again. “You can do it.” Excruciating. His MOM enters the room. GREG’S MOM Honey?

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: What. He looks up. His mother looks stricken. GREG’S MOM Honey, Rachel’s back in the hospital.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: Wait--is she starting treatment again?  Blue (6/3/14) 84. GREG’S MOM It’s not for treatment, honey.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: Oh. His mom waits for him to say something.

dialogues.speaker: GREG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Mom, what. GREG’S MOM I just thought we could go--

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: You just figured this was your last chance to force me to hang out with her? GREG’S MOM Greg, come on--

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: Don’t worry, mom. I’m sure you can find some other girl with cancer after Rachel dies. Which, by the way, she’s decided to do. She's decided to die. So maybe I can decide not to visit her. GREG’S MOM I promise you will regret it if you don’t visit her. You will regret it for the rest of your life.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: (exploding) Yeah. That’s probably true. But you know what? I have a shitload of things to regret. I regret not having a date for tomorrow’s stupid prom. I regret being too weird to make friends. I definitely regret making those shitty films with Earl. And I assume you saw the email I got today from Pitt State, when you were going through my stuff - no? You didn’t? Oh! Have a look! He opens an email on his phone and tosses it to his mom.

dialogues.speaker: GREG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm probably gonna regret doing literally no schoolwork this year!  Blue (6/3/14) 85. GREG’S MOM (in shock) Oh my God, Greg--

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: I know! Admission rescinded! Due to “significant change in my academic record”! Oh well! No college! I guess I'll just be home next year! I know, it sucks. It’ll be way harder for you to go through my stuff. His mom, horrified, says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: GREG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But for right now, do me a favor. And just leave me alone. I just want to sit here and regret stuff. I’m gonna think of everything I’ve ever done, and everything I haven’t done, and just regret the living shit out of it. 79 EXT./INT. GREG’S BEDROOM - THAT NIGHT 79 GREG is watching his animation and his sock puppets and listening to HIS PARENTS argue through the walls.

dialogues.speaker: GREG'S MOM, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (tearfully) The deadlines have passed, Victor! What’s he going to do next year? Is he just going to waste his year?

dialogues.speaker: GREG'S DAD, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: He is grieving, honey. You have to let him grieve.

dialogues.speaker: GREG'S MOM, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: How can you tell me to just do nothing while he ruins his life?

dialogues.speaker: GREG'S DAD, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: That’s not what I’m saying. The conversation continues as Greg watches his video.

dialogues.speaker: BECAUSE I DON'T GIVE A SHIT
Unknown
dialogues.text: Once again, GREG is eating alone under the prom banner, w now has the word “TONIGHT !!!!!"” added to it. And maybe more gratuitous quotation marks.  Blue (6/3/14) 86. And again, Madison comes to sit with him. Super: The part where I get in my second fight ever

dialogues.speaker: MADISON
dialogues.text: (hesitantly) Greg? Can I ask you something? Greg gathers his things and gets up.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: Nope.

dialogues.speaker: MADISON
dialogues.text: It’s not what you think-- ALT: It’s not what you think. It’s about prom-- Madison touches his arm, but he shrugs it off, angrily--

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: (interrupting) Let me ask you something--what is this? What is up with the arm- touching? Greg is backing away from her now. She is following.

dialogues.speaker: GREG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Are you just being friendly? Or is it, like, this calculated tactic? To get me to do whatever you want? Because you have to understand what it does, when a beautiful, sexy, otherwise thoughtful girl touches the arm of a scrawny pasty guy with a groundhog face. It’s an act of cruelty.

dialogues.speaker: MADISON
dialogues.text: Are you done?

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: Yeah, I’m done with you. And I’m done with the stupid film. He backs into ILL PHIL.

dialogues.speaker: ILL PHIL
dialogues.text: But you ain’t done with me.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: Oh come on.  Blue (6/3/14)

dialogues.speaker: ILL PHIL
dialogues.text: You’1l never escape me. Nobody rats me out and lives to tell about it. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: ILL PHIL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm back for my revenge / Stab you in the dick, pardon my French / Shove your body under a bench /

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: (frantic) Are you honestly gonna stab me? Fine. Go for it. You’re gonna go to jail for your entire life, but, it’s probably worth it. Stab away. Ill Phil is not prepared for this. He was hoping Greg’s reaction would be more along the lines of running away.

dialogues.speaker: ILL PHIL
dialogues.text: You lucky I ain’t got my knives. Stead you gotta fight me, punk.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: Sure. I’1l fight you. Just no rapping. They square up. Onlookers excitedly gather, including a grimly snickering SCOTT MAYHEW. Neither Greg nor Phil makes a move for a long time. They actually have no idea how to fight.

dialogues.speaker: ILL PHIL GREG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (muttering rap) Break your eyeball with a Stop. fist I got clenched / Take your teeth out with a Seriously stop. wrench / Hit you with a stone from I can’t do this if you’re Stonehenge / gonna rap the whole time. Finally Ill Phil swings and Greg grabs his arm. But then doesn’t know what to do with it.

dialogues.speaker: ILL PHIL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (thrashing a little) Leggo my arm.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: Okay. Jesus.

dialogues.speaker: SCOTT MAYHEW
dialogues.text: Phil! Remember how he has trampled our dignity! More circling. The onlookers are becoming restless. Final Greg rushes Ill Phil and grabs him around the waist. I1l panics and grabs Greg around his waist.  81 82 Blue (6/3/14) 88. They stay like that for a while. And then, suddenly, EARL flies in and starts whooping ILL PHIL’S ass. The CROWD goes berserk. Almost immediately, the PRINCIPAL separates the fight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The PRINCIPAL and a SECURITY GUARD are leading/dragging E GREG, and ILL PHIL to the nearest school exit.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: (to Earl) I thought you were eating lunch in Mr. McCarthy's office.

dialogues.speaker: EARL
dialogues.text: He all sad. Talkin bout German music or something. I was like, dude. This is boring as hell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The PRINCIPAL, SECURITY GUARD, GREG, EARL, and ILL PHIL emerge from the doors.

dialogues.speaker: PRINCIPAL
dialogues.text: (to Greg and Earl) Two days’ suspension for fighting. Two days’ suspension for fighting. (to Ill Phil) Two days’ suspension for fighting to be added to your lifetime suspension for drug dealing. Please leave school property.

dialogues.speaker: BOYS
dialogues.text: Yes sir/Awright. As they begin walking away, MADISON approaches them.

dialogues.speaker: MADISON
dialogues.text: Greg.

dialogues.speaker: MADISON
dialogues.text: Come to prom with me. Even Earl does not know what to say here.

dialogues.speaker: MADISON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Look. You were right. This whole movie situation has been really difficult for you, and I feel like it’s my fault. I want a chance to make things up to you a little bit.

dialogues.speaker: ILL PHIL
dialogues.text: Yo, you can make things up to me. (beat) You want my number?

dialogues.speaker: EARL
dialogues.text: (to Ill Phil) Ain’t nobody want your beat-ass number. You are going to die alone.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: So this is a pity date?

dialogues.speaker: MADISON
dialogues.text: It’s not a pity date. She smiles.

dialogues.speaker: MADISON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I think we'd have fun. INT. GREG’S BEDROOM - THAT EVENING 83 GREG is putting on his tuxedo. He is having some trouble the arms. His MOM is standing by the door. GREG’S MOM I told you you would get a date.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: Yup. GREG’S MOM So, you're welcome. For the tuxedo and everything.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: Thanks Mom.  84 85 Green (06/20/2014) 90. GREG’S MOM I am very unhappy about this college thing. But your father and I can wait until you're ready to talk about it.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: I appreciate that. GREG’S MOM Let me help with your corsage. She does. Greg examines himself in the mirror. GREG’S MOM (CONT’D) My handsome boy, going to prom. Take lots of pictures, okay? Greg does not answer. He’s busy looking into the mirror. anxious boy in a tuxedo stares back out at him. EXT. IN FRONT OF GREG’S HOUSE - EVENING 84 GREG, holding corsage, walks stiffly into a limousine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GREG is alone in the back of a cavernous limousine. He ha shout to reach his cheerful DRIVER.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: 302 Halket Street.

dialogues.speaker: LIMO DRIVER
dialogues.text: You got it, boss. They drive. LIMO DRIVER (CONT’D) You love this girl?

dialogues.speaker: GREG
