dialogues.text: Uh. I dunno if I would go that far.

dialogues.speaker: LIMO DRIVER
dialogues.text: Are you kids gonna get busy on my brand-new Tuscan leather?

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: I think the odds are against that.  86 87 Green (06/20/2014) 91.

dialogues.speaker: LIMO DRIVER
dialogues.text: Ha. I’m just playing with you, man. I hope you do get some.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: Thanks. It’s really gonna depend on what she wants to do.

dialogues.speaker: LIMO DRIVER
dialogues.text: Well. If you really love her, you got a shot. Because she’1ll know. Greg does not respond to this. LIMO DRIVER (CONT’D) She is fine, though?

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: I wouldn’t say that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GREG exits the limo, holding his corsage. He is not in front of Madison’s house. He is front of the HOSPITAL. He takes a deep breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RACHEL is suffering from pneumonia, a complication of end stage AML. She is extremely pale and having difficulty focussing. But she smiles when GREG walks in. SUPER: Day 209 of Doomed Friendship DENISE, sitting next to her, smiles with wet eyes, gets u and hugs Greg for a very long time. Then she leaves the r

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Hey. Her voice is weak and whispery.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: I know. I look amazing. Here, let me put flowers on you.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Thanks.  88 Blue (6/3/14) 92. He puts the corsage on her wrist. It is not romantic. It something else. He extracts his phone and a little projector from his poc and starts setting them up -

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: Before we watch this, uh... I’m really sorry it took so long to make. But the reason for that is, we couldn’t figure out how to not get it to suck. And we never did figure it out. It still sucks, and it’s not actually what I wanted to say to you. But let’s just watch it first. Okay? She nods. He turns on the projector. It projects onto the curtain. sits next to her, and they watch for a while. The film does, as advertised, suck. First, there are the TESTIMONIALS: students sitting in a classroom, saying clichéd things, or unhelpful things. So those suck. DENISE’S INTERVIEW has been jarringly edited so as not to depressing, but of course this makes it even more depress It goes without saying that this sucks. And spliced among all of these sections is a mysterious ANIMATION that is never explained and never gets enough t to develop. It’s confusing. How could that not suck? As they watch, Rachel begins to cough, weakly. Greg ignor this for a few coughs. Then he realizes that it isn’t going away.

dialogues.speaker: GREG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Should I get a nurse? Rachel, nods, coughing, in pain.

dialogues.speaker: SLIGHTLY SLOWED DOWN, SOUND MUFFLED
dialogues.text: GREG emerges from the room. DENISE is asleep in a chair outside. He jogs her arm. She wakes up, reads his face, a rushes into the room, stricken.  89 90 Blue (6/3/14) 93.

dialogues.speaker: GREG, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: That was the last time I saw Rachel. She went into a coma shortly after that, and died about ten hours later. Greg flags down a passing NURSE and says something to her Irritably, she walks into Rachel’s room, shutting the doo behind her.

dialogues.speaker: GREG, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Yeah. I know I told you she didn’t die. But I mean... this is a story about a girl with cancer. Greg is left alone in a hospital hallway.

dialogues.speaker: GREG, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: What did you think was going to happen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GREG, EARL, and MR. MCCARTHY are sitting all in a row, ne the back. The forceful inner-city PRINCIPAL is speaking.

dialogues.speaker: PRINCIPAL
dialogues.text: It is indeed a difficult time... for the Schenley High School family. We are mourning... a family member. But we have an unexpected and touching opportunity... to turn our thoughts to her... in a unique way. (with God’s own voice) EARL JACKSON. GREGORY GAINES. Please come to the stage. Greg's heart skips a beat. His eyes widen with terror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From the hall, through the half-open door, DENISE watches film projected on Rachel’s curtain.

dialogues.speaker: PRINCIPAL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: These boys made a film... that they delivered to Rachel last night.  91 92 93 Blue (6/3/14) 94.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO THE PRESENT
dialogues.text: Earl has his head deep in his hands. INT. TEACHER’S CONFERENCE ROOM - FLASHBACK, EARLIER THAT TEACHERS and the PRINCIPAL watch the film on a computer. are very moved. They are watching a sock puppet part.

dialogues.speaker: PRINCIPAL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And her mother has given us permission... to show you this film now.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO THE PRESENT
dialogues.text: Greg and Earl are up on stage. Cataclysm. It is, literall the stuff of nightmares.

dialogues.speaker: PRINCIPAL
dialogues.text: Before we show the film... Is there anything you would like to say... to the Schenley High School family. Earl walks to the lectern. The mic is nowhere near his he The PRINCIPAL, noting this, removes the microphone and ho it to Earl’s mouth.

dialogues.speaker: EARL
dialogues.text: Naw.

dialogues.speaker: PRINCIPAL
dialogues.text: You will let this audacious film speak for you. Very good. Gregory? Greg staggers to his feet. He takes the mic. He gazes out his classmates. He has nothing to say to them. But he can’t just say noth Suddenly he begins speaking.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: This film sucks. And after you watch it, you’re gonna think I’m this pathetic untalented loser. But here’s the thing: I don’t care what you think about me. I’ve spent the last four years obsessing over how everyone sees me, and I just realized, I don’t care anymore. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: GREG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The only person whose opinion I care about is dead. So, whatever. He puts the mic down, then decides to pick it back up.

dialogues.speaker: GREG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’ve always wanted never to be noticed by anyone. But the best way not to be noticed is to be dead. And I don’t want to be dead. He puts the mic back. The principal, frowning, walks over reclaim the mic. Then Greg abruptly grabs it a third time.

dialogues.speaker: GREG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Wait. Here’s why our film sucks. It’s not the film we should have made. Okay? Because I wasn’t even friends with Rachel before she got sick. And then she got sick and we spent all this time together, but it wasn’t enough. It just wasn’t. To make the film we should have made, we should have gotten her to tell us every single thought she has ever had. Because it’s all just lost, now. We should have had a camera on her, constantly, since the day she was born. Because her whole life, now, it’s just lost. We should have had a camera inside her head, because all of her specific thoughts and ideas and hopes and phobias and all of her impressions of the whole stupid world, they’re all about to be lost, and the film we should have made would keep her from being lost. And I know that happens to everyone. It’ll happen to everyone in this room. And it'll happen to me. But I don’t care. All that I can think about is that it happened to her. And it happened last night. And I can’t deal with it, I’1l never be able to deal with it, and this film has nothing to do with that. Nothing. (forcing back tears--semi- incoherent) It sucks. Nothing sucks more than this. It sucks.  94 95 Blue (6/3/14) 96. He puts down the mic and walks, then runs, offstage and o of the auditorium. The students are baffled. Some of them giggling, but from nervousness. Earl has his head in his hands. The lights go down.

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED 94
dialogues.text: INT. RACHEL’S LIVING ROOM - AFTERWARD 95 MOURNERS wander around Denise’s house, sitting shiva. GREG spots MADISON and SCOTT MAYHEW together holding hand talking to DENISE. Surprised and sickened, he avoids them He gazes, from afar, at the URN on the mantel that contai Rachel’s ashes. He cannot stop looking at it. It is absur him, in a way. Suddenly he has been cornered by an OLD PERSON -

dialogues.speaker: ELDERLY MOURNER
dialogues.text: I heard you made a very nice little movie about Rachel’s life.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: Oh. Uh, yeah.

dialogues.speaker: ELDERLY MOURNER
dialogues.text: When will it be in theaters?  Blue (6/3/14) 97. Greg does not have the heart to set this doddering old pe straight.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: Soon. Really soon. I’m sure Denise will let you know. Can you excuse me for a moment? Greg sneaks into the kitchen. He looks around for a place where he can escape all human contact. He gazes out the window, to the backyard, and sees someon EXT. RACHEL’S BACKYARD - A FEW MINUTES LATER 96 EARL has spent most of the shiva outside smoking irritabl GREG approaches him.

dialogues.speaker: EARL
dialogues.text: Look who it is.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: Sorry, I haven’t been out of my room for a few days.

dialogues.speaker: EARL
dialogues.text: Yeah. I know. You smell terrible.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: I can’t really smell myself.

dialogues.speaker: EARL
dialogues.text: (matter-of-factly) You smell like a homeless dude. And I heard even Pitt State ain’t takin you no more.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: Yeah, well. Whatever. The backyard door opens. DENISE.

dialogues.speaker: DENISE
dialogues.text: Hi boys.

dialogues.speaker: EARL GREG
dialogues.text: Mrs. Kushner. Mrs. Kushner. I mean, Denise. Denise is holding Greg’s COLLEGE DIRECTORY.  Blue (6/3/14)

dialogues.speaker: DENISE
dialogues.text: Greg, I’m supposed to give this back to you. She does. And retreats back to the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: DENISE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (smiling sadly) Squeak squeak.

dialogues.speaker: GREG EARL
dialogues.text: (agreeing) (begrudgingly) Squeak. Squeak. Denise enters the house. Greg holds the college directory doing nothing. A couple of envelopes fall out. He opens one.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Dear Greg. I heard what happened with your classwork, and with Pitt State. So I wrote them a letter trying to convince them to let you back in. There’s a copy in here if you want to read it. Hopefully it works, because that would mean I have powers from beyond the grave. But you should probably send them something too. Goodbye, Greg. You’re a good friend. Although if you don’t go to college, you’re also an idiot. But you already knew that. Love, Rachel. At “goodbye,” Greg's eyes blink and go wet. He unfolds the second letter--

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Dear Pittsburgh State Admissions, I am writing on behalf of someone so kind and sweet and giving that he -  Blue (6/3/14) 99. He closes it. He can’t read another word. He closes his e Earl clears his throat.

dialogues.speaker: EARL
dialogues.text: I know it’s a bad time. But I ain’t doin them films with you no more. Greg throws up his arms, like, Jesus Christ. Like it’s no already gut-wrenching enough out here.

dialogues.speaker: EARL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I ain’t. I can’t. I’m done.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: EARL
dialogues.text: I'ma level with you. I never even liked makin the damn films. I like watchin crazy-ass films. But I hated makin em.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: Earl, you're the talented one. You’re the one who’s supposed to do this with his life.

dialogues.speaker: EARL
dialogues.text: Oh hell no. That’s you. That ain’t me. I ain’t gonna be a broke-ass artist. (beat) Me, I want to end up like your dad.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: (momentarily shocked out of misery) What?! Greg peers through the window at his DAD, who is alone in middle of the living room, scratching himself.

dialogues.speaker: EARL
dialogues.text: Listen, son. I’m just tellin you. Your dad’s around. He around all the damn time. Fact he around too much. Talkin to the cat, starin into space. But to hell with it. That’s gonna be me. Serve my kids funky-ass food, show em films with subtitles. Wear random ethnic shit. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: EARL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And I ain’t getting there by spendin all my time makin films. That is not a foundation for a comfortable life. I need a career. (not wanting to say this) I’m goin to Duquesne. Pre-law. Don’t tell nobody.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: Oh. ...Earl I had no idea th--

dialogues.speaker: EARL
dialogues.text: (needing to move on) Don’t be tellin nobody. Now, you. You too weird to start a family. So you can go ahead and do your broke- ass artist thing. That’s fine. Run out of money. You can come live in my garage, with the raccoons. Me, I’m makin a comfortable life. No more films. I’m out. Silence. Earl notices GREG’S MOM watching them through the window. She hesitates. But she can’t help herself. She gestures t “smoking” to Earl, then gestures “death,” then gives him look of reproach. Earl shrugs, baffled. She sticks her head out of the window - GREG’S MOM (whispering) Earl, it’s a little inappropriate to be smoking a cigarette outside of shiva. Of someone who had cancer. Oh. Earl philosophically stubs out his cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: EARL
dialogues.text: Sorry Mrs. Gaines. She closes the window -

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: I’m out too. I’m not making films anymore either. I’m retired.

dialogues.speaker: EARL
dialogues.text: No, you’re not.  Blue (6/3/14) 100A. This next thing is hard to say.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: Earl. If you quit, I have to quit. Earl looks Greg in the eye. Greg means it.

dialogues.speaker: EARL
dialogues.text: Listen. From now on, I'ma be your audience. And I’ma watch everything you make. Even if it’s terrible. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: EARL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And it probly will be. You probly ain’t shit without me. But that’s what friends do. They gotta watch. Even when they hate that shit. Yeah. I called you my friend. I’m your friend. Deal with it. Greg is beginning to cry again. Earl eyes him doubtfully.

dialogues.speaker: EARL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And you quit, I’ma beat the hell out of you. All right?

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: All right.

dialogues.speaker: EARL
dialogues.text: I done it before. I'll do it again. It’s easy as hell. Because you don’t know how to fight.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: All right.

dialogues.speaker: EARL
dialogues.text: Goddammit stop cryin.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: I’m not c-crying.

dialogues.speaker: EARL
dialogues.text: Cryin like a bitch. Earl, after a resentful pause, puts his arm around Greg. pats Greg on the shoulder a few times.

dialogues.speaker: EARL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (irritably) Feel like we're having a goddamn breakup right now. C’mon. Let’s go inside. Earl goes into the house. Greg just watches him quickly become engulfed by the adults in there. He looks over at the FIRE ESCAPE leading to Rachel’s bedr window. INT. RACHEL’S BEDROOM 97 GREG steps through the window and into Rachel’s room, the book under his arm, the letters in his hand. He sits on her bed. Surrounded by pillows.  Blue (6/3/14) 101A. He takes another look at the letter to him.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: P.S. I’d also like for you to take some of my pillows. They’1ll want a good home where they’1l be loved. Greg picks up Francesca.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: P.P.S. Not in the way you’re thinking. That’s disgusting. He gazes at the walls. Daniel Craig, Hugh Jackman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 98 Blue (6/3/14) 102. He looks down at his directory. He opens it - The inside has been CARVED OUT, intricately, into a littl landscape. He is motionless, gazing at it. It is beautiful and stran There are three small figures in it. Somehow we know they Rachel, Greg, and Earl. Rachel’s has pink hair. He runs a finger over the lip of this little fantastical place that her hands made. He gazes at her bookshelf. He pulls out a book - no carvi in there - another one - again no carving - another - This one is carved out too. A different landscape. Two figures - Rachel (the same color, but her old brown hair) one who is probably her mom. He finds more and more. A world of landscapes. Different styles, from different times in her life. Sometimes he kn who the figures are, and sometimes he doesn’t. The figure that is her is always recognizable. There is no broad narrative connecting them. They are jus scenes. Not necessarily from her life - perhaps something tangent to it. At some point we are no longer seeing the book carvings - are just watching his face, as he SEES in a way that he n has before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Greg walks home slowly, eyes fixed on something unseeable somehow released, Rachel’s house behind him. INT. GREG’S BEDROOM - NIGHT 98 We're back to where we started: GREG staring at a compute monitor, breathing loudly through his nose.  Blue (6/3/14) 103.

dialogues.speaker: GREG, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I know I might seem to you like I hate myself and everything I do. But really, I just hate everyone I’ve ever been. The person I am right now is okay. Rachel’s ashes were scattered in a park behind her house. Apparently she ran away from home once and tried to live there. It was this story her aunt told at the funeral. She was trying to become a squirrel. She thought she could turn into one by just being in the forest and wanting it really bad. I guess maybe that’s what Mr. McCarthy meant, about someone’s life continuing to unfold. It was weird to be learning something new about Rachel after she died. But somehow it was reassuring as well. The printer has just stopped printing the story we have j been told. On the back we see the words, “Somehow it was reassuring as well. FIN.” He puts it in an envelope addressed to Pittsburgh State University - Department of Admissions. And then he puts a DVD in a jewel case. And then he stick Post-It on top of the case, and writes, “WARNING: THE LAS

dialogues.speaker: PERSON WHO SAW THIS IMMEDIATELY WENT INTO A COMA AND DIED
dialogues.text: And he puts that in the envelope as well. He seals the envelope. He stares directly at us. We look into his eyes. He crosses them, briefly. BLACKOUT.
